I told the customer the price was non negotiable and we would therefore be cancelling the job. We should have every right to charge what is a fair price, and feel it is quite wrong for a customer to try and force a price reduction on what has already been agreed and scheduled in.. We have spoken to checkatrade about this, but have been told that despite appealing, the feedback will be published, therefore vindicating the customers actions. We feel this is quite wrong. I did ask to speak with a manager within the complaints team, but never heard back.

title: Score Breakdown
text: We have done several jobs at this property, often at very short notice and unsocial hours as we appreciate the occupant is very elderly and vulnerable. With this particular job we responded the same day and out of hours. We spoke with the carer regarding toilet replacement and both agreed further works regarding flooring and boxing-tiling could be done after the toilet install. He was more than happy with this as it meant time without a functioning toilet was kept to a minimum and the follow on works with a third party could be scheduled at their convenience.We were contacted by the elderly gentleman's son six weeks after fitting the replacement toilet. I assume this is the first time had seen the installation. It is unfortunate that he had not been involved at the outset as if we had given a different remit we could have given timings and costings accordingly. We did offer to reattend but this was declined. This feedback isn't a fair reflection of our company. title: Score Breakdown
text: I would like to issue the following response to this feedback, We are surprised and upset about these comments as the customer gave no indication whatsoever that they were unhappy with our service, at the oustset the customer was advised tiles would need to be removed in order to investigate-trace the leak, and they were happy for us to proceed. We also advised that we would be happy to reinstate when the job was completed. With reference to the shower valve, we were acting directly from advice from the manufacturer's technical department which the customer was fully aware of as the phone call was made at his property and in his presence. It is rather puzzling why the customer asked us to return to carry out further work if they were so unhappy with the original work? If any customer is unhappy with our service we would bend over backwards to turn this round, but we were never given this opportunity. The customer never made us aware of any dissatisfaction, complaining and expressly asking that we do not contact them. Please view all other customer feedback for a more accurate indication of our workmanship and ethics.

title: Score Breakdown
text: I was asked to perform a boiler service.  When I arrived I was directed to the boiler. As I approached the boiler there was a very strong smell of gas. I performed a gas tightness test which confirmed there was a gas leak. I established that all pipework up to the boiler was sound, and the leak was from within the boiler. I stripped the boiler, tightened and checked all accessible connections using leak detection spray, but was unable to pinpoint the leak. During this investigation a small wet patch of water had formed under the boiler and the boiler's pressure gauge was showing a drop in pressure. I advised the customer I was going on holiday that day and I would arrange for a colleague to further complete the investigation. Due to the gas leak, under gas safe guidelines the boiler had to be classified as immediately dangerous and the gas supply isolated to the appliance. I feel the customer became threatening and I was told to leave the house. In my van I telephoned national grid gas emergencies to inform them of the incident. As a gas safe registered engineer there are strict safety procedures that we have to adhere to. I have a duty of care to my customers.
